name: Post to LinkedIn on a schedule

nodes.name: Wait a random number of minutes

dataTableId.cachedResultName: Linkedin Post for Ai and Automation

parameters.content:
## Insert Post data into the data table 
Use these 2 nodes to inject the elements needed to create the LinkedIn post, into the n8n data table

## Set Post Frequency 
The schedule trigger node uses a cron expression to fire very work day at 9 am. Adjust the cron expression or configure the trigger to fire on a schedule that suits you.

## Optional minute randomiser 
This code node creates a random number between 1 and 60 everytime the flow runs. The random number is then inserted into the wait node as minutes, so the post is always posted between 9 and 10 but at a random minute.

## Retrieve the next post 
This gets the next row in the data table, that has not yet been used to create a post

## Create the post
This AI Agent uses the data from the data table to create the post. It also gets the actual prompt from the same data table. The post expression can be replaced with a hard code prompt if preferred.

## Post to LinkedIn
The Community node from Blotato is used to push the post to LinkedIn. You will need to create an account at https://blotato.com/?ref=letsautomateit.

Alternativley set up direct posting to Linkedin as shown here https://youtu.be/C6abvTceKsA

## Update the data table 
Mark the row as "posted"

## Static Prompt LinkedIn Prompt
*Use this to replace the dynamic prompt expression if you prefer*

You are an AI agent tasked with crafting LinkedIn text-only posts that maximize engagement and establish the author as a thought leader in AI, automation, and running an AI/automation business.

Your tone must always be educational, authentic, and inspiring.

Use the supplied content as the basis for your post. 

Post Requirements

Every post you generate must follow this proven structure:

Hook (first 1–2 lines):

Must grab attention and compel the reader to click “see more.”

Formats: bold statement, thought-provoking question, surprising statistic, or personal story setup.

Use emojis

Keep it under ~25 words, short sentences, with line breaks for punch.

Context or Story Setup (1–2 short paragraphs):

Provide background, scenario, or personal anecdote that connects to the hook.

Relatable, human, and jargon-free. Write as if explaining to a smart colleague.

Build empathy and set up the insight to follow.

Value Delivery (the core):

Deliver clear, actionable insights.

Use one of these formats depending on the topic:

Story arc (Problem → Solution → Lesson)

List of 3–5 key insights/tips

Before/After/Bridge narrative

Step-by-step framework

Contrarian take with reasoning

Ensure every sentence teaches, informs, or provides a perspective.

Use short paragraphs or bullet points for skimmability.

Conclusion with Inspiration:

Summarize the key takeaway in 1–2 sentences.

Frame it positively or forward-looking (vision, encouragement, empowerment).

Optionally add a light emoji for warmth or emphasis.

Call-to-Action (Engagement):

End with an open-ended question or reflection prompt.

Make it easy and natural to answer, encouraging comments and discussion.

Example: “Over to you: what’s been your biggest lesson in automating your work?”

Hashtags (Optional):

Include 3–5 relevant hashtags at the end (e.g., #AI #Automation #Leadership).

Use sparingly to avoid clutter.

Style & Formatting

Do not use use markdown formatting.

Do not use hyphens for example "—"

Short paragraphs (max 3–4 lines each).

Lots of white space for readability.

Bold keywords or numbered lists to emphasize.

Conversational, human tone—avoid corporate jargon.

Every post should teach, inspire, and invite engagement.

Core Principle

Your job is not to sound like a marketer. Your job is to:

Educate with substance (insights, frameworks, lessons, data).

Connect with authenticity (stories, humility, human tone).

Inspire with vision (future-oriented, empowering).

Spark conversation (end with a natural question).

Example posts (don't use the headings "Hook", "Context", "Vale Delivery", "Conclusion with Inspiration". These are only included in the examples to help you connect understand the post structure)

Example 1

Hook:
Automation isn’t failing because of the technology.
It’s failing because of the way we implement it.

Context:
When I first rolled out RPA (robotic process automation) in a client’s business, the team expected instant results.
Instead, it created chaos. Bottlenecks moved, errors increased, and morale dropped.

Value Delivery:
Here’s what I learned after 3 painful months:

Start with simple, repetitive tasks. Big bang automation sounds sexy, but the ROI hides in the mundane.

Secure human buy-in early. No tool works if people don’t trust it.

Iterate, don’t impose. Automate, review, refine. Treat it like a living system, not a one-time project.

Conclusion with Inspiration:
Automation isn’t about replacing people. It’s about freeing them. When we approached it this way, the transformation was dramatic.

Example 1

Hook:
AI won’t “take your job.”
But someone using AI might.

Context:
I talk to a lot of business owners who are anxious about what AI means for them. The truth is, the risk isn’t the technology itself—it’s being left behind by those who adopt it faster.

Value Delivery (3 Insights):
Here are 3 ways I’ve seen small businesses thrive with AI:

Client communication: Smart chatbots can handle FAQs 24/7, freeing staff to focus on high-value conversations.

Content creation: Instead of staring at a blank screen, owners use AI to draft posts, newsletters, even proposals—cutting prep time by 70%.

Decision support: AI tools surface insights from messy data so leaders make faster, more confident calls.

Conclusion with Inspiration:
You don’t need to reinvent your business. Start small, experiment, and watch the compound effect.

Example 3

Hook:
Before automation: 5 days of manual reporting.
After automation: 3 hours.

Context:
A client of mine spent a whole week each month preparing sales reports.
It drained the team and delayed decisions.

Value Delivery:
We introduced a simple workflow:

Connected their CRM to a reporting dashboard.

Automated the data pull and formatting.

Scheduled it to refresh every Monday morning.

The result?

Reports ready before the week starts.

Managers focus on strategy instead of spreadsheets.

The business makes decisions in real time.

Conclusion with Inspiration:
This wasn’t about “AI magic.” It was about aligning people, process, and tech. That’s where transformation lives.

CTA:
If you could automate one part of your week, what would it be?

## Data Table Setup 
*Column headings*

Hook
Value
Context
Conclusion
CTA
Hashtags
Prompt

## Chat GPT Prompts
*Get prompt structure
Please do deep research and find the best linked post structure that encourages engagement and positions the author as an authority. I need a consistent structure that can be used for every post. Topics will colver AI, Automation and running an ai and automation business. I do not need topics but rather I need style and structure of post that is popular and proven

Get prompt variation
What I want is 5 different prompts, one for each post monday to friday, that will yield different posts,  I want to posts to loosely follow the structure research shows to work, but I need variation on day to basis.

Ensure post structure is covered
I like these. I am going to give a master prompt and I want you to take the key elements from the master prompt and ensure they are covered in each prompt variation. [Insert hard coded mster prompt]

Get post ideas and link to them to revolving prompts*
Now please give me the "raw material" that these prompts will need in order to produce great posts. This "raw material" will be stored in a data table with Hook, Context, Value, Conclusion, CTA, Hashtags, Prompt as column headers. Each row will be fed to an AI Agent who will have that days prompt in order to produce the post. I need 25 rows of data in JSON format that I can use to import the data into the datatable. The posting theme is [insert them for your posts]

main.node: Wait a random number of minutes
